title: Magnetism - identifying polarity with known magnet

content.question: A student is given a metal bar with ends labeled <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. The student suspects that the bar may be a magnet and wants to determine which end of the bar is magnetic north. The student brings end <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> near the north end of a bar magnet and observes that the two ends attract. Which of the following best describes the polarity of end <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> before the student brought it near the bar magnet?

choices.label: End <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> must be magnetic north.
End <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> must be magnetic south.
End <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> may be magnetic south.
It is impossible to determine if end <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is magnetic north or south with this information.

content.answer: End <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> may be magnetic south.
